item.title: Ticket #2356 (Image names using the single quote character cause problems in ...) created
item.dc:creator: dmetzcher
item.description:
I submitted this to the WP support forum as well: ​http://wordpress.org/support/topic/58689

I uploaded an image with the following name "Running 'sudo periodic daily' in the Terminal" (notice the two single quotes used in the name). When I uploaded the image, I was unable to use the image upload interface to add the image to my post. I would click the image, and nothing would happen. I verified that this issue was present in Firefox 1.5 and Safari 2, both on Mac OS X. I also verified that other posts with images worked just fine, until I clicked Browse All, and then none of the images, on any posts, would display the popup menu asking me what I wanted to do with it. This was not just affecting the image with the name containing the single quotes, it was affecting all images displayed along with that image in the upload window. If that image was not present in the list, the other images worked fine.

I corrected this by going into the wp-posts table in the WordPress database and looking for the post (post_status=attachement) that contained the information for my image. I edited the record in question, taking out the single quotes in the name, and everything was back to normal.

Not sure what caused this, but it should be pretty easy to reproduce.

item.title:
Ticket #2348 (
blahblah
breaks themes, validation) updated
item.dc:creator: davidhouse
item.description:
I spent some time bouncing ideas off skeltoac in #wordpress, here's the problem as I understand it in other words in case anyone didn't quite get that brief description:

TinyMCE likes to use divs for various pieces of structure. This is fine until you put a more tag in the middle of one, because we trim everything after the more tag sometimes. This means that all nodes open when the more tag comes along will not have closing tags when we strip. That's okay when the open tag is just a P, the browser can cope. But when its a DIV, the entire structure of the theme could and does get messed up.

What Andy's patch does is any time we need to display the trimmed version is to pass said version through balanceTags to make sure this kind of lost-closing-tag doesn't crop up.

item.title:
Ticket #2348 (
blahblah
breaks themes, validation) created
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description:
TinyMCE produces code like that sometimes. If it were a P tag it would only break validation; because we don't nest P tags the browser closes the P when it reaches the next /DIV. However, because themes generally give one DIV per post, nesting goes all awry when a /DIV is missing from within a post. It causes all following posts to nest and, in most themes, indent. The effect is cumulative with multiple split posts, as often occurs on home pages and in archives.

We should fix any nodes broken by the "more" split in get_the_content().

The attached patch makes it possible to force balanceTags to ignore the option so we can use it to fix the split post in get_the_content(). I profiled this in the ZDE and found that balanceTags took a negligible .14-.49ms per split post. It is not run on posts that are not split.

The patch also includes an optimization in get_the_content(), replacing a preg_match() with a strpos().

item.title: Ticket #2003 (Permalinks fail when using the same permalinks and category base) closed
item.dc:creator: davidhouse
item.description:
wontfix:

Think about it:

/archives/%postname% is your permastruct, and /archives your category base. That means permalink URLs will be something like /archives/my-wonderful-post, and category requests something like /archives/my-wonderful-category. How is WordPress meant to distinguish between them? We could possibly check the slug against both posts and categories, but what if you had a post the same name as a category?

Solution: don't let your permalinks clash like this.

item.title: Ticket #2347 ("core_files_loaded" action cannot be used... get rid of it!) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Skeltoac pointed out something to me in #wordpress: the "core_files_loaded" action hook is useless. It happens immediately after functions are loaded (so right after add_action() becomes available), but before my-hacks.php and plugins are loaded. Furthermore, plugins are loaded right afterwards... so there's no need for a hook there... a plugin can just run its code "live." I've commented the action out (no harm, nothing can use it, and no one is even trying) and marked it as deprecated. 

skeltoac: MarkJaquith: What kind of person would use the "core_files_loaded" hook?
skeltoac: That's the hook that comes just before my-hacks and plugins.
